docs.abstract: Dr Jay Gladstein letter on Jane Brody's December 23 Personal Health column discussing obesity and diabetes agrees that American diet is major health problem (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re the Personal Health column ''Stampede of Diabetes as U.S. Races to Obesity'' (Dec. 23):
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re the Personal Health column ''Stampede of Diabetes as U.S. Races to Obesity'' (Dec. 23):

headline.main: Dividends for the Young and Fit

docs.abstract: Northwestern University Dr Mercedes R Carnethon publishes results of study on early fitness and effect on future problems with high blood pressure and diabetes in Journal of American Medical Assn; findings show that individuals testing at low fitness levels at ages 15 to 30 are three to six times as likely as more fit contemporaries to have diabetes or high blood pressure 15 years later; drawing (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A study over 15 years has found that people approaching middle age were more likely to have high blood pressure and diabetes if they did poorly on treadmill tests as young adults, ages 18 to 30. The findings suggest that it is important to lay the groundwork for cardiovascular health early.

headline.main: Advertising; An antispam law, new questions for food and drug advertising and optimism for a new year.

docs.abstract: Article on optimistic prospects for advertising industry and upcoming issues, including antispam law, Food and Drug Administration proposals to change its guidelines governing direct-to-consumer drug advertising and controversy over obesity and advertising of nutritionally suspect food (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the advertising industry, the first of many changes expected next year will descend as soon as Thursday. That is when a law takes effect that regulates the unsolicited commercial e-mail almost universally derided as spam. The act may ease the problems associated with spam -- which now accounts for half of all e-mail traffic -- by banning false or deceptive headers on a message that can disguise the sender's identity and empowering the Federal Trade Commission to create a ''do-not-spam'' list, among other measures.
